text: uh hi everyone Anthony fantano here
internet's busiest music nerd I hope you
are doing well and it's time for a
review of this new album from bjerk
fasora this is the latest full-length LP
from the legendary Icelandic singer
producer songwriter bjerker 10th we have
not heard a new LP from the Art Pop goat
since uh 2017's flute heavy Utopia which
was a pretty flowery and ornate change
of pace from the sorrowful and
heartbroken vulnera just a few years
prior post pandemic I was pretty curious
to see what shape a new Bjork record
would take especially considering the
singles building up to this thing like
the very challenging and Urgent octopus
which sees Avant Opera vocal soaring
over these honking Reed harmonies and
like a reggaeton Groove being played out
with these perks that are very loud very
rigid not a whole lot of body to them I
presume because of the subtle gabber and
hardcore techno in influences that come
out on this record here and there
especially in the latter half now this
very unlikely combination of sounds
comes with a message about the increased
isolation of society from itself it
seems in a post-quarantine and
increasingly digital world bjerk is
seeking some kind of human connection
the sentiment of the track is a little
on the nose but well-intentioned and I
mostly feel the same way about the
following track ovule which features a
lot of very plainly spoken romantic
imagery the horn harmonies throughout
the track are great but a lot like the
opener the super rigid beats and
one-dimensional progression of the track
doesn't really leave a lot to be excited
about there's something about the
movement of these tracks or lack thereof
that just feels a bit off moments like
the first two tracks here feel less like
songs and more like a slightly pompous
musical theater piece which read like
they were inspired by a vivid fever
dream that continues building up tension
for a release that never really comes
and rather than continue building on
these sounds we get a few sudden shifts
in the tracklist instead there is
Mycelia which is one of a handful of
interludes on this thing this one's like
a bare synthesized vocal piece for the
medulla heads it's okay but it passes by
without much of anything stunning going
on then sorrowful soil also leans pretty
heavy into the group vocal passages it
is a bit longer and the performance is
legitimately beautiful but it's overall
lack of development leaves this track
feeling like a motif of sorts too though
I will say the lyrics on this track do
add to a pretty key theme on this LP and
that is motherhood procreation familial
love bjerg works this angle in a pretty
interesting way not merely by just
writing about it but also by leaving
space for a couple vocal features on
this record from her own children
syndrie lends his own voice to the
following ancestrous which in my opinion
is the record's first real stunner and I
think it achieves these Heights by
avoiding the rigid progressions and
overbearing beats that uh previous
tracks on this thing embrace the
beautiful ascending Melody and Lush
instrumentation on this track just
develops in this very open and fluid way
and it just results in a very
Fantastical and enchanting seven minutes
that I love getting engrossed in
lyrically this track also seems to be in
tribute to bjork's late mother who's
passing undoubtedly impacted the themes
of this record things further disperse
stylistically from here on the record
which makes it difficult to see really
what direction things are going in we
have another very loose interlude before
we get the cut victimhood who's very
dark and evocative first half puts me in
a vastly different place than any other
tracker Moment On This Record does but
the second half where all of these uh
various vocal leads and read Melodies
are just layering over each other in a
super chaotic way yeah this section is
much less gratifying and feels almost at
odds with itself which may have
something to do with the song's own
commentary on victimhood and self-pity
which I think can read as sort of
invalidating if taken a certain way the
second half on this thing is a bit
stronger and is kicked off by the song
allow which has a lot of very Baroque
and fluttering Woodwinds on the intro
taking us right back into Utopia
territory given the bright and hopeful
vocals and lyrics as well as the
atmosphere surrounding this track I
wouldn't be surprised if it was like a
holdover from that era and it's
certainly nice while it's on but it's
instrumental palette and mood just feels
utterly disconnected from nearly every
other moment on this record thus far
fungal City featuring serpent with feet
feels a bit more like it given what the
teasers of the album panned out to be
the Reeds make a very bold return with
some meticulously composed passages the
Beats take a more subtle Approach at
first eventually building up to this
really hardcore pounding sound and level
of volume which honestly I think was the
move the overall progression of the
track is much more tasteful for it
following this we have by far the worst
interlude on the entire record which
legitimately sounds like something off
of a a very creepy spooky Halloween
effects tape but I suppose we do get
some pretty strong closing moments on
the lp there's the stunning vocal and
string combo on Free Fall which hits a
very emotionally overwhelming Peak uh
one of the most beautiful I've heard on
a Buick record in a long time totally
enamored with it even if the track does
kind of Trail off toward the end and
it's the title track of the record in my
opinion where those gabber influences
those Reeds and those somewhat operatic
vocals and harmonies come together in
the most explosive and exciting way the
read Melodies are fantastic and very
expansive the Beats take their time
reaching a very explosive Peak I get
that maybe what this album is doing
overall is far from bjork's most
accessible sound palette but uh it's
it's intriguing all the same we have a
pretty low-key closer from here
featuring vocals from bjork's daughter
we have lyrics on this track about home
and instilling things like compassion
and love into your children it's
obviously very clear this record is
trying to convey something about raising
kids about child rearing and certainly
make a statement as well with this
combination of very rigid beats and the
Reeds during key moments like the intro
and the title track but but but but but
when we look at the record as a whole in
my opinion it doesn't really dig into
these themes and Sonic ideas all that
deeply by Bjork standards this doesn't
really feel all that close to a complete
idea a totally explored concept and
historically bjerk is really truly
someone who tends to drill down into
things we've seen it again and again and
again from medulla to volnikura to
biophilia by comparison phosora just
seems so much more surface level even if
it does deliver some mind-bending
moments here and there so as a result of
that as well as some very weak cuts that
pale in comparison to others and some
ill-conceived ideas and some half-baked
progression here and there I'm pretty on
the fence with this record honestly so
sadly I am feeling like a light too
decent five on this one
uh transition have you given this record
to listen did you love it did you hate
it what would you rate it you're the
best you're the best what should I
